Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 53264-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
August 2021 
 
 
India: Enhancing Market Linkages for Farmer 
Producer Organizations 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 9 August 2021) 
 
Currency unit  –  Indian rupee/s (₹) 
 
₹1.00  =  $0.01347 
$1.00  =  ₹74.24 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  JFPR  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
  MAGNET  –  Maharashtra Agribusiness Network  
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  VCO  –  value chain operator 
 
 
NOTES 
(i)  The fiscal year of the Government of India and its agencies ends on 31 March.  
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Director General  Kenichi Yokoyama, South Asia Department (SARD)

(SAER); SARD

CONTENTS 
 
Page 
I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  1 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  2 
A.  Justification  2 
B.  Outputs and Activities  2 
C.  Cost and Financing  5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  5 
 
APPENDIXES 
1.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  7 
2.  List of Linked Documents  8

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  Maharashtra is the leading contributor to India’s economy, accounting for 14.3% of the 
national gross domestic product in fiscal year 2020. However, the state is also ranked among the 
highest in the income and development inequalities, as economic development is concentrated 
only in major cities. The central and state governments target to raise farmers’ incomes by 
promoting agribusiness development and aggregating crops of small and marginal landholding 
farmers through organized farmer producer organizations (FPOs). Horticulture crops such as 
fruits, vegetables, and flowers have high value but are highly perishable; almost 40% are lost or 
wasted in different stages of the agriculture value chains. The losses can be reduced by proper 
post-harvest practices and agriculture value chain facilities. The project is also built on the grant 
project funded by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR), which piloted promotion of 
horticulture FPOs in Maharashtra.1 
  
2.  The  proposed  Maharashtra  Agribusiness  Network  Project  will  support  the  state 
government of Maharashtra through a holistic approach combining a project loan and financial 
intermediation  loans.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  achieve  average 
agriculture sector growth rate of 5%; promote agriculture produce export; and establish fair, 
competitive, and accessible agriculture markets.2 The project’s outcome is that Maharashtra’s 
horticultural production values and FPOs’ profits will be increased. The outputs comprise (i) 
institutional,  technical,  and  marketing  capacities  of  agribusiness  institutions  and  FPOs 
strengthened; (ii) access to finance of FPOs and value chain operators (VCOs) strengthened; and 
(iii) agriculture value chain infrastructure improved and operational. The project is estimated to 
cost $142.9 million, of which $100.0 million will be funded by Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
ordinary capital resources (regular loan). 
 
3.  The project has the following innovative and demonstrative elements. This transaction 
technical assistance (TA) will support delivery of the following finance-plus elements and replicate 
them within and outside India through the capacity development resource center in the India 
Resident Mission, workshops, and regional forums including ADB’s Rural Development and Food 
Security Forum.3  
(i)  Innovative technology. Based on a list of innovative technologies identified 
during  project  preparation,  the  project  will  (a)  directly  apply  some  to  facility 
improvements, (b) give guidance to FPOs and VCOs, and (c) promote their 
application through financial support.4 These technologies cover various stages of 
agribusiness such as aggregation, storage, processing, logistics, and marketing 
including digital agriculture services for direct marketing and higher sales prices.5 
(ii)  Centers of excellence network. Capacity development activities will be linked to 
research and development activities of  the National Institute of Post-Harvest 
Technology and associated research centers. A network of institutions will be 
 
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2010. Improving Small Farmers’ Access to Market in Bihar and Maharashtra.  
Manila (Grant 9147-IND); and ADB. 2020. Improving Small Farmers' Access to Market in Bihar and Maharashtra: 
Maharashtra Implementation Completion Memorandum. Manila. 
2  State Government of Maharashtra Planning Department. 2017. Vision 2030. Mumbai. 
3  Finance-plus refers to value addition beyond monetary support given through loan and grant financing. 
4  A currently expected list of technologies and their explanations is available from ADB. 2020. Strengthening Capacity 
to Design and Implement Water and Rural Infrastructure Facility: Technical Assistance Consultant’s Report. Manila. 
5  ADB’s pilot study in April–May 2020 demonstrated generation of new sales opportunities for 540 farmers and faster 
and safe delivery of fresh products to consumers with the use of an e-commerce platform and online logistics 
services. Digital traceability systems benefit value addition in farmers’ produce, safety certification for consumers, 
and price transparency. Smallholder farmers can also benefit from digital agriculture services that provide market 
intelligence; precise weather and harvest advisories; and access to quality inputs, logistics, and financial services.

2 
developed to holistically provide support to FPOs and farmers on good agricultural 
practices, new crop varieties, and other technical innovations. 
(iii)  Exemplary value chains led by farmer producer organizations. The project will 
develop exemplary value chains led by FPOs which successfully link with rapidly 
growing retailers and bring higher FPO shares in sales revenue. 
(iv)  Value  chain  acceleration.  The  newly  established  Maharashtra  Agribusiness 
Network (MAGNET) Society will be developed to be a value chain accelerator, 
which will offer crop-based support to develop FPOs and collectively market their 
products with higher brand values.  
(v)  Gender mainstreaming and social inclusion. The project will support poor and 
vulnerable small-scale farmers to enhance their income opportunities. Mahila 
Arthik Vikas Mahamandal will depute staff and work with the MAGNET Society to 
ensure that women and FPOs and VCOs owned or led by women are promoted 
and given priorities in capacity development and financial support. The gender 
equality and social inclusive action plan will enhance inclusive project benefits to 
women and other vulnerable groups. 
 
4.  Follow-up actions from the previous Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction grant. The 
JFPR grant project (footnote 1) was implemented from July 2010 to December 2018 to enhance 
integration of small-scale horticulture farmers into modern value chains by (i) organizing farmers 
into farmer groups, (ii) building their capacity to increase production, and (iii) establishing market 
links. The grant project was implemented successfully with most of the targets achieved, including 
establishment  of  1,404  FPOs  and  delivery  of  capacity  enhancement  trainings.  The 
implementation completion memorandum suggested the following follow-up actions: (i) continued 
support  to  FPOs  and  farmer  producer  companies  is  necessary  to  develop  their  technical 
knowledge of modern farming practices; (ii) strengthening buyer–seller links should be considered 
to ensure sustainability of project outputs; and (iii) participation of women should be ensured in 
agriculture and value-addition activities. The proposed project and this TA were built on the 
successful implementation of the JFPR grant and will address the follow-up actions. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The proposed project will provide ADB’s value addition through the finance-plus elements 
with support from the proposed TA. The TA will complement the proposed project by introducing 
international good practices and providing capacity development to the MAGNET Society and 
other stakeholders in the finance-plus elements. The TA is proposed to be attached rather than 
be made part of the loan to maintain continuity with ADB’s past TA support and allow for efficient 
consultant management and close supervision by ADB. This transaction TA is listed in the country 
operations business plan for India, 2021–2023.6 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1. Outputs 1 and 2 will be 
financed by the JFPR,7 and outputs 3 and 4 will be financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance 
 
6  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: India, 2021–2023. Manila. The TA was envisaged for only $1 million 
to be financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), but the amount was increased 
during the project preparation stage to ensure sustainable project results and mitigate implementation risks. 
7  The JFPR is a possible funding source subject to Government of Japan approval.

3 
Special Fund (TASF-other sources). All the relevant activities to be conducted under the TA will 
reflect Japanese visibility based on the Guidance Note on Japanese Visibility.8 
 
Table 1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities 
Delivery 
Major Outputs  Dates  Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Crop-based  Q2 2024  1.1 Identify at least 12 anchor FPOs and potential FPOs (including at 
centers of  least 20% of the FPOs to be women and led by women) for the target 
excellence  horticulture cropsa to be supported in 6 months. 
networks  1.2 Identify  crop-wise  center  of  excellence  network  for  capacity 
created and  development activities for each of the 11 target cropsa comprising the 
capacity  NIPHT, anchor FPOs, and other agencies and organizations within 6 
development  months. 
on value chain  1.3 Develop crop-wise assessment and proposals on (a) market access 
acceleration  and  expansion  for  both  domestic  and  export  markets  including 
conducted  branding  concepts;  (b)  trade  volume  and  price  projections  and 
targets; (c) quality requirements of key customers and markets and 
existing gaps; (d) facility requirements, utilization, and gaps; (e) 
mechanisms and instruments to make value chains more effective 
such as testing and grading, food safety, and dispute resolution 
mechanisms of contract farming; and (f) capacity development plans 
of FPOs to enhance their business, financial, and technical capacity 
and utilize high-level and innovative agriculture technologies and 
female members within 6 months. 
1.4 Prepare crop-wise midterm (3–5 years) action plans based on above 
1.1–1.3 to accelerate value chain activities and enhance market links 
within 8 months and update the plans in a rolling manner at the 
beginning of each fiscal year by validating all business assumptions, 
developing annual plans, and defining key performance indicators. 
1.5 Organize and conduct market promotion events such as buyer–seller 
meetings and e-marketing promotion annually from the 8th month 
(5,000 or  more  participants in total, of which at least  15%  are 
women). 
1.6 Develop training materials and train the trainers through the centers 
of excellence network based on the action plans continuously from 
the 9th month (100 or more trainers to be trained, of which at least 
20% are women). 
1.7 Coordinate trainings to FPOs to be conducted by the trainers and 
organized by the PISC from the 9th month continuously throughout 
the TA implementation period (35,000 or more participants in total, of 
which at least 20% are women). 
1.8 Prepare knowledge products to be used for replication of the project 
experience and expertise and disseminated through (i) the INRM’s 
CDRC to other states of India, (ii) ADB’s Rural Development and 
Food Security Forum to other member countries and development 
partners, (iii) ADB’s website to development partners and general 
audience, and (iv) other means. 
2. High-level and  Q2 2024  2.1 Review outputs of high-level technology consultants and project 
innovative  preparatory consulting firmb and other relevant documents within 1 
technologies in  month. 
agribusiness  2.2 Develop training material and train the trainers in anchor FPOs and 
and agriculture  other interested FPOs through the center of excellence network from

2.3 Promote  application  of  high-level  and  innovative  technologies 
including  digital  transformation  through  project  activities  in

2.4 Prepare knowledge products to be used for replication of the project 
experience and expertise and disseminated through (i) the INRM’s 
CDRC to other states of India, (ii) ADB’s Rural Development and 
Food Security Forum to other member countries and development 
partners, (iii) ADB’s website to development partners and general

3. Capacity  Q2 2024  3.1 Review outputs of post-harvest management and direct marketing 
development  studiesc and other relevant documents within 1 month. 
on post-harvest  3.2 Partner with successful extension service providers that use both 
management  women's networks in villages and technologies for dissemination and 
conducted  adoption of modern post-harvest processes (outputs of post-harvest 
management and direct marketing studies above) especially among 
women and vulnerable groups for value addition and higher wage as 
reward. The visual extension materials of 10 crops prepared under 
the post-harvest studies can be utilized and improved as necessary 
and be focused on female workers for dissemination. 
3.3 Identify women and vulnerable groups’ agribusiness marketing best 
practices  which  show  success  in  crop  marketing,  post-harvest 
process, and local door-to-door logistics and delivery business; and 
work  with  these  women's  self-help  groups  to  replicate  their 
successful business models for other women's groups. 
3.4 Assess effective use of drones and other technologies for crop 
disease and pest monitoring, best harvest timing projection, and 
logistics arrangements. Conduct training in coordination with the 
PISC  and  target  especially  women  and  vulnerable  farmers  as 
operators. 
3.5 Enhance the centers of excellence network on horticulture post-
harvest management, marketing, and good agricultural practices with 
the  NIPHT  as  the  hub  and  integrate  successful  post-harvest 
demonstration groups above within 12 months. 
3.6 Conduct capacity development including training of trainers on post-
harvest management, marketing, and good agricultural practices to 
MAGNET Society staff, anchor FPOs, and other stakeholders within 
24 months. 
4. Asset  Q1 2022  4.1 Assess  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  the  existing  asset 
management  management  and  maintenance  policy  and  develop 
and financial  recommendations to improve them within 3 months.

Society and  practices and other recommendations within 5 months. 
MSAMB 
improved  
CDRC = Capacity Development Resource Center, FPO = farmer producer organization, INRM = India Resident Mission 
(of the Asian Development Bank), MAGNET = Maharashtra Agribusiness Network, MSAMB = Maharashtra State 
Agricultural Marketing Board, NIPHT = National Institute of Post-Harvest Technology, PISC = project implementation 
support consultant, Q = quarter, TA = technical assistance, VCO = value chain operator. 
a The target crops are bananas, custard apples, green and red chilies, guavas, okra, oranges, pomegranates, sapotas, 
strawberries, sweet limes, and flowers.

5 
b Engaged under ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance to India for Strengthening Capacity to Design and Implement Water 
and Rural Infrastructure Facility. Manila. 
c Conducted through ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Building Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Asia 
and the Pacific (Phase 1). Manila. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.5 million, of which (i) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and (ii) $2.0 million will 
be financed on a grant basis by the JFPR and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
8.  The government will provide counterpart support estimated at $0.3 million in the form of 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will administer the TA. The Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division 
of the South Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The TA will be 
implemented over 36 months and is expected to start in August 2021 and end in August 2024. 
The state of Maharashtra, acting through the MAGNET Society, will be the executing agency. 
 
10.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2. 
 
Table 2: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  August 2021–August 2024 
Executing agency  The state of Maharashtra, acting through the MAGNET Society 
Implementing agencies  ADB through the South Asia Department 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Firm: QCBS  Enhancing Market Linkages for  $2,460,000 
(90:10)  Farmer Producer Organizations 
Individual:  International and national  $40,000 
individual selection  expertise (4.5 person-months) 
Advance contracting and  Advance contracting will be undertaken for recruitment of the 
retroactive financing  consulting firm and individual consultants. 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). TASF and JFPR funds will be disbursed on a pro rata basis. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, JFPR = Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, MAGNET = Maharashtra Agribusiness 
Network, MSAMB = Maharashtra State Agricultural Marketing Board, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection, TASF 
= Technical Assistance Special Fund. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
11.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.9 
 
9  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

Note: The technical assistance (TA) is estimated to cost $2.8 million, of which contributions from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) and the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) are presented in the table above. Funds from ADB and 
the JFPR will be disbursed on a pro rata basis to a consulting firm, and only funds from ADB will be used for an 
individual facility management and maintenance specialist. The government will provide counterpart support in the form 
of counterpart staff, office accommodation for meetings, office supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind 
contributions. The value of government contribution is estimated to account for 12.0% of the total TA cost.
